body.p:
You will think I have quite forgotten your favor
of 5th inst. which I received the day after Hebrew, but however
improbable it may appear to you, I have not had a minute
for letter writing since the holy days. You know I teach
the children Hebrew, and the number has greatly increased-
-but you do not wish to know how I have been employed

You need not thank me for the almost nothing
I have done, & would do for any one under the same circumstances.
The two Daily Prayers sent will I presume soon go, but
not the Catechisms. If I am to collect the amounts
due you for Bibles &c you had better enclose me a slip
which you can send with the next Occidents, something
in this form. I hereby request & authorise NDS to
collect ? It is useless to refer in this again to what
has so long passed, but I am not the only one who
thinks I had cause to be disappointed in your
course towards me. You stated in the Occident I had done you
wrong. I deny this as emphatically now as ever
My conduct towards you was honest fair and above
board, although I know you conveyed a different

impression to mutual friends, upon whom however
it had no effect. I yet think were you to review all
you would find I had some good grounds for my opinion.
Had matters so turned out with any other than yourself
I should long since have ceased to think of that with
derision and contempt; but it was a hard thing to be
branded as something mean and vile by one whose good
opinion had ever been so prized by me, and which had
ever been so flattering. I always am prepared to admit
that misrepresentation, antagonism & jealousy of you
were rife, but I deny before my maker that these
feelings ever actuated me; that I did or said anything
that after the best reflection I thought calculated to
injure you or your chances of re-election on your
own terms, or that I ever had any feelings towards
you but of respect & esteem. You will never
know how, even since the appointment of your
succession to office, I have been invited from other
quarters than Philadelphia (let me add this, for I
would not wish you even to suppose for a minute
that your successor was one) to engage, humble as
my position is, in various things which could only
be injurious to you. I do not desire to embitter
your intercourse with those men in office with
whom you must even if occasionally only come
in contact, but I have convincing proof of

my having been charged deemed guilty of insincerity by you
without cause. I at one moment was on the point of
showing you this, but second & better thoughts came.
You had already publicly pronounced your opinion, though
as a sincere friend you had no right to condemn me
so quickly & unheard, Hebrew, and Hebrew you
had forgotten. When a line from New Orleans would have
settled all, your dignity would not permit you to realize
that if there is Hebrew there is also Hebrew. I had
never thought to have written, at least not to day
on this subject, one so fruitless of result, as it necessarily
must be, but as it is written it must go. Perhaps
were we living in the same city, some good result
might be arrived at. At present I think of Hebrew

Had I had time I would have written you before
to tell you of my fathers having informed me a few weeks
since of your ? to him about the Prayer Books.
He writes me he would address you by the same packet
so you will learn from himself the reasons for declining
I would have told you myself of his going on as far as
his third vol. The first has been for some time
in Montreal, & last August I saw it in New York.

Apropos des bottes, what else but an obstructive
policy did you expect there, unless a little or small policy
I hope the Hebrew may find not duly find a field of
usefulness sans obstructions but also a bed of roses
-not Hebrew-though I feel disposed sagely
to shake my head & say I have my doubts.
